summary: Two green reporters and rivals working for the Washington Post, Bob Woodward (Robert Redford) and Carl Bernstein (Dustin Hoffman), research the botched 1972 burglary of the Democratic Party Headquarters at the Watergate apartment complex. With the help of a mysterious source, code-named Deep Throat (Hal Holbrook), the two reporters make a connection between the burglars and a White House staffer. Despite dire warnings about their safety, the duo follows the money all the way to the top.

reviews.content: Director Alan J. Pakula handles matters in All the President's Men the way any good journalist tackles a story – factually, objectively, succinctly.  The story is centered around Bob Woodward (Robert Redford) and Carl Bernstein (Dustin Hoffman), reporters for the Washington Post who help to unveil the biggest scandal in American politics – Watergate.  While it may be helpful to have some background on the story before watching the movie (there are a ton of players involved that may be hard to keep track of), it remains a gripping story, even fifty years after the scandal originally broke.  Hoffman and Redford are great, the supporting cast is impressive, and William Goldman's screenplay keeps things moving at a nice clip.

I'm not into politics, but this was gripping. I kept watching. The plot, dialogue, and character interactions were all good. The ending is quite haunting, with the cut off of no music. I think it's appropriate considering this is the reality of the situation. There is no flashy finale, just contrast of Nixon being reelected with silence.
Solid acting, solid story. Not a classic, but enjoyable nonetheless.

Journalism movies are my second favorite type of movies and this might be the best one I ever watched, together with of course Spotlight. The screenplay is smart and still mysterious, you really don't know till the end hoe they are going to expose them, the camera work in particular was incredible and the editing, flawless movie
Great movie and really well done. Well acted and a cool perspective for a true story

Stunning, big budget docudrama, the kind we don't see much of any more.  Most of the dialogue is improvised; Pakula gives the actors bullet points to bring out in a scene, and then the actors stumble through the conversations live like that for the audience; which gives the film a real immediacy.  Great acting and production values but the star here is really the story.  An important film which helped galvanize the public in their collective referendum on Nixon's guilt in the Watergate scandal.
This is masterpiece. Solid direction, glueing, and great cinematography. One of few films you can watch multiple times. This film just made the scandal interesting even I born decades after that.

Incredibly Well Done Political Thriller Classic. The cinematography on display here is exquisite. Along with phenomenal acting, amazing editing and a very well paced plot that is hard to turn away from despite knowing the outcome of this historical event. This film is more a salute to investigative journalism rather about Watergate and that is where the one flaw of this film occurs. This movie is VERY heavy if not one of the heaviest on exposition and there are many different names your expected to remember and time of events and its hard to put a mental picture in your head because you can't put a face to all these people and it isn't really something you can just leave up to your imagination like the shark in Jaws for most of the film. This makes it feel VERY dry at certain points and more than likely these names were very well known and common knowledge only 2 years after Watergate but harder for someone who didn't grow up during these events. Despite that it is still extremely well done and keeps you engaged despite the exposition overload and is a great classic New Hollywood Film and a classic Political Thriller. Very Highly Recommended.

I feel like it most definitely could have used more film editing. I suppose they were going for the more raw film to make it feel more real but it didn't work for me. Also, even if you're interested in the Watergate scandal, this movie is exceptionally boring with a really lackluster air-out-of-the-balloon ending.

Robert Redford and Dustin Hoffman portray Carl Bernstein and Bob Woodward in this excellent film adaption of the book "All the President's Men." This movie focuses on the unraveling of the Watergate Scandal by the Washington Post staring Robert Redford and Dustin Hoffman. The pair work off each other seamlessly in this excellently acted, directed, and produced to bring the political thriller to audiences. This movie cemented the idea that political thrillers can be as entertaining and fun as  other dramas during the 1970's. I highly recommend audiences go out and see this movie as younger audiences will be informed and older audiences will be nostalgic of the Watergate Scandal.
Fantastic movie. Perfect acting and plot. The fact that it requires no music or dramatic sound effects to create genuine suspense and interest speaks to its quality. Flawless masterpiece - 5/5

Behind the story, All the President's Men a non-fiction book, Robert Redford is having a great credit...

Writer, William Goldman did a good job for the script...

Director, Alan J. Pakula supervises with excellency...

This film has a strong supporting casting and well equipped facilities, e.g. Jason Robards being "Ben", George C. Jenkins and George Gaines as Art Direction, Arthur Piantadosi, Les Fresholtz, Dick Alexander and James E. Webb as film sound...

Of course, Dustin Hoffman as Carl Bernstein as well as Robert Redford as Bob Woodward should gain all my credits...

I saw this movie again for the second or third time tonight. It really holds up well in my view, and they say that a lot of other films have taken inspiration from it over the years, among them Spotlight and The Post. 

I really love the scenes in the newsroom. They claim that the filmmakers went to great lengths to recreate the offices of the Washington Post, and it really does look and feel like what a newsroom may have been like in that era. 

On a side note, I'd be interested in knowing a little more about the influence that the novel All the King's Men might have had on this film. It seems likely that it takes its title from that book, which explores a corrupt governorship in Louisiana in the 1940s.

An incredibly well-crafted paranoia thriller about one of the greatest real-life political scandals in America. You may know the ending, but it's the thrill of finding out how we got toward that conclusion in the first place which makes this film so appealing. Our two protagonists don't transform or go on any character arc, but they're played by talented performers and their earnest pursuit of getting to the bottom of things is enough to align us with them. It's not an easy film to follow, and I think that adds to it. You feel like you're alongside Woodward and Bernstein, trying to keep track of all the names and all the remaining leads and how they all connect and make sense. It's a delightful scavenger hunt that brings out some of the most raw tension there is, aided by the realistic dialogue from William Goldman and the lack of a score. It's better on second viewing and I imagine it will be  so on the third.

"Hold it."
The Watergate story which made tremble America. A nearly naturalistic movie, very close to reality (as the two journalists were there and Hoffman spent weeks at Bernstein sides). It's a page of history, printed on celluloid, written by two unknown journalists. It's the power of people, democracy.

Based on the true story of two reporters who wouldn't give up on the story of Watergate, this movie is as gripping as any detective novel.  Producer/star Redford was so intent on authenticity that he even flew actual garbage from the Washington Post waste baskets out to the set.  The movie does a good job of showing how much of the work of the reporters was dull persistence and it also does a good job of showing us what went in to the decisions of editor Ben Bradlee and publisher Katharine Graham about what they need in terms of proof in order to publish the story.

The movie showcases an interesting range of moral choices and calibrations.  The famous Deep Throat still unidentified when the movie was filmed, is someone from the inside who won't allow himself to be identified or quoted but is willing to confirm what the reporters are able to find elsewhere.  Others involved int he scandal, both the corruption itself and the cover up, must decide what to do and how much to disclose.  One key development is the decisions made by someone identified only as, "the bookkeeper" to talk to Bernstein.  The participants must also deal with the consequences of their choices.  Donald Segretti manages to evoke sympathy when what began as juvenile pranks leave him in disgrace.  Woodward and Bernstein also make mistakes and must deal with consequences.

Singularly, one of the best movies ever made. The corruption around the Kennedy and King assassinations ultimately ended up here and tricky dicky was sent packing. He should never been anywhere near the presidency.

A distanza di pochissimo tempo da uno degli scandali peggiori che ha investito la storia degli USA, questo capolavoro si pone come pietra miliare per coraggio e per lo straordinario impatto sul pubblico.
Mai prima di allora, un atto del genere, fu riportato sullo schermo in maniera tanto fedele da poter sembrare un vero e proprio documentario se non fosse per i volti noti degli attori; un nuovo genere cinematografico fu creato, e venne mostrato al mondo quanto questo strumento potesse essere utile anche per riportare ciò che realmente accade.
Ovviamente la sceneggiatura è unica e anche i protagonisti sono di un livello altissimo e completano alla grande l'opera. Capolavoro.
Peccato per il finale agrodolce e con alcuni aspetti solo riassunti nei secondi finali.
Really liked the work of Gordon Willis.

86%. Kind of hard to decide because very well made and a lot of excitement and intrigue but doesn't have quite enough to push it over. Learned a lot about watergate so was very interesting. Definitely glad I watched it. Not something I'd seek out rewatching on my own but worth a rewatch if I wanted to learn about the scandals again or someone else wants to see it
one of my all time favourites - great rendition of a real event
Powerfully acted and masterfully written. All The President’s Men shines a light on a dark era in politics that was relevant at the time and even more so today.
a technical wonder that impresses deeply and leaves lots to chew on.

Not only are the leads excellent in the roles, this film is riveting from start to end.  Excellent supporting cast including Jack Warden and Jason Robards.  
Excellent film.
Good movie. Hoffman and Redford do two great performances.

I first saw this movie when it was released here in the UK. I struggled to follow it as a 15 year old, but I was mesmerized nonetheless - understanding it was a significant film about an equally significant event. Now into my 60s I really can't say how many times I've viewed it - maybe 100 times or more - and there's always something there I hadn't clocked before. I've already watched it twice this month. Anyway, who cares what I think - just go for it - my only advice - listen to every word, take notes and watch it sober. Hugely rewarding on every level.

There is some great acting here but the bottom line, the story is confusing, and the ending to be is very strange. It seems to end with denials from everyone as if nobody has taken the allegations seriously. We then see captions stating dates of when the individuals involved resigned. Surely there was more to the events that needed to be included in the film?

Another brilliant movie portraying the role of true journalism in countering the fallacies and political manipulation of the government along with great performances . Given the details of facts it almost feels like a documentary turned into a movie .
Makes you want to be a journalist... Robert Redford is magnificent here.

This movie will make you believe in the power of the pen and the profound importance of journalistic integrity. In a world where misinformation spreads like wildfire and even the most reputable publications are called into question, it's a breath of fresh air to revisit a time when the fourth estate meant something.

This might be the most boring thriller I have ever sat through which is meant as an absolute compliment to Pakula who was able to, as Woodward and Bernstein did with the source material, create extreme tension and interest with the dull and unsexy type of crimes that usually won't make it into the films. This is an excellent book and I was surprised how well the film was able to hold up to it.

A good journalism and investigation film, good performances, ambience and a certain dynamic; I believe that to fully enjoy it you need to understand the real story on which the film is based, (for those who are not Americans like me), but I recommend studying after seeing the film because it spoiled my experience, took away my element of surprise and the step by step of the investigation; but I recommend understanding this moment in the history of the United States because it influenced all pop culture, which includes films, series and music.

This movie tells how Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein worked to see what really happened at Watergate. It is a good movie about journalism and how it can be to try to uncover stories. In my opinion, they could have shortened it a couple of minutes, but still a great movie.
Well acted, powerful, and really intense.

Though many can't deal with writer's or how they operate, this movie was phenomenal in it's day and age and still works as it is. Part suspense, part intriguing, and being fact based it leads credence to it. Both actors play off each other and submit well to it. A well solid piece of entertainment.

Has certainly losts its pang for over 4 decades ago but nonetheless a well acted and interesting political thriller, if not bogged down. And, I hate to say it, but quite slow/hard to get into. Certainly works better in novel format. Suprisingly striking visuals.

With charismatic leads and a very fresh, timeless feel, All the President's Men crackles with a modern feel and a palpable relevance.

Little details, such as the difference in the way Redford and Hoffman type is a great indicator of their differences, and the film is moody and yet also brisk.

The split diopter shots are always excellently conceived and used, doubling down on the notion that intimate and powerful moments occur in an open plan and busy arena, all night filled with the kind of intensifying the glare of these artificial environments and their depth and parallel lines.

The photography is stunning, the colours in what must have been a 4K remaster, popped and felt realistic and perfectly tuned. The film is very very funny and the score stays out of the way to make the story the focus and the emotions muted even if the effect of their work was loud.
Brilliant movie, and the discussion before and after was also wonderful.

How funny that two films tackling the direction of journalism in the late 1970s were released in the same year and took completely different stances on the nature of journalists and the reaction of the public to them. This film is earnest and treats journalists as idealistic social justice crusaders who want the public to know the truth while Network (1976) is far more cynical and presents us with ratings-obsessed businessmen who want a good story at any cost. Of the two I must say that I found a lot more to enjoy in Network which despite being a satire felt more realistic and had more to say about journalism. This film presents us with two romanticized figures who are so by the book in their pursuit of the truth that it is hard to believe them as real people in addition to not being drawn in by their false perfection. Adding to this lack of interest was the film's extraordinary length as a story that could have been told in a tidy 100 minutes, thriller elements and all, is stretched out over 138 minutes. All in all a film that will satisfy aspiring journalists hoping to ‘save the world' but for a slightly more cynical viewer they may take agin the phony ideals the film offers.

Washington Post journalists Bob Woodward, Robert Redford, and Carl Bernstein, Dustin Hoffman, investigate government corruption in 1972 after the Watergate Hotel is broken into. Woodward uncovers a trail of corruption leading to the White House after discovering that the burglars are connected to former government employee E. Howard Hunt. Using "Deep Throat", a shifty government employee, Woodward is able to verify information and is encouraged to "follow the money" in order to connect the break in to President Nixon. With the help of bookkeeper Judy Hoback Miller, Jane Alexander, they put together a story they can put to print and expose the corruption of the President.

The free press clearly have something to offer society as they supposedly provide us with un-biased information on political and social issues that educates us and holds the government accountable. However I do not believe that journalists are actually altruistic in their pursuit of a good lead. They have egos like everybody else and considering the amount of self promotion that Woodward and Bernstein dished out I believe that they knew they were onto something and felt a certain amount of satisfaction at having found a story that would make them famous. None of this is present in the film as our two crusaders are angelic in their commitment and devotion to their work and other than references to Bernstein being a womanizer and Woodward being to uptight they lack humanity. The great journalists in cinema have been flawed, tragic individuals such as J.J. Hunsecker in Sweet Smell of Success (1957) who are riveting even as they abuse the ethics of their profession. Seeing two ‘nice' men go about their job while facing very few barriers or challenges was hardly compelling and one would like to see more out of a film featuring Hoffman and Redford.

Remarkably the conspiracy they uncover seems less interesting than it should be as although it was a shocking bombshell at the time you never feel the abject horror that the public must have felt in the film. I wanted to be shocked and horrified as I was at the end of The Conversation (1974) but Pakula lacks the ability of Francis Ford Coppola to convey mental turmoil in the minds of characters. When Woodward runs down a darkened street in fear of being attacked by one of Nixon's associates I felt certain that nothing would happen to him and even if he had been beaten I doubt I would care. His ambitions were direct and straightforward, his reactions limited and this meant that even the moments of supposed excitement in the film are not as joyous as they should have been. Were Pakula to explore the idea that journalists are so jaded that they aren't exhilarated by a conspiracy of this scale I could have appreciated the dour, glum tone but instead he plays everything straight faced and that just wasn't enough. 

If you want a fascinating Pakula directed thriller that manages to explore the emotional struggle of the main character effectively please seek out Klute (1971).
An exciting film about journalism, based on the true Watergate story.

William Goldman's direction in "All the President's Men" stays focused on the Watergate investigation by the Washington Post with impressive technical skill as well as benefits from the power of its two leads (Redford and Hoffman), but we already know the ending so the payoff isn't as satisfying as you'd like from such a significant moment in American politics.

A masterclass film anchored by the two leads, especially Redford.  Also, Redford directs this film the best possible way you could of.  Based on the true story that's clouded with webs and webs of information and motives, this film wonderfully explains all of it with style and excitement

The movie is an accurate representation of how important print media was before the internet came along. Media as information is the root of this movie. The entire movie is a good example of media as information. A majority of it is filmed inside the Washington post office space where journalists are dedicating their life's work to investigating and writing stories for the public.
It's an important story, and everything is done well. It just is slow-paced and could've benefited from more (character) conflict.
All The President's men is a beautifully made, complex, well acted, political thriller. One of the best of the year.

In the beginning, Redford and Pakula said, "let us make the journalistic thriller in our image, in our likeness, so that it may rule over all the theater screens across the country and all the shelves at the Best Buy 'classics' rack, over every wannabe Spielberg pre(?)-make and over every lowly serf that thinks you absolutely need explosions or killings in your movie for it to be any good." "All The President's Men" is just plain ol' cracker-jack storytelling. Though, yes, it most certainly helps that the story in play is already fascinating enough -- and true, to boot -- it also doesn't hurt to have one of the world's greatest screenwriters staging your scene dynamics, drafting up your dialogue, and structuring your overall narrative. Aside from William Goldman's expertly constructed screenplay, this also just so happens to represent Alan J. Pakula putting on an absolute clinic in how to make a seemingly dry movie look incredible. From the dank, expressive corners of a darkened parking structure, to the blindingly bright interiors of the Washington Post's office floor, it all feels expertly staged and shot. Oh, and Redford and Hoffman are pretty damned good as well. Not that that needed clearing up or anything. In the end, "All The President's Men" is an engrossing, beautifully realized story of power, journalistic integrity, and the importance of getting/making things right.
A highly-enthralling portrait of one of America's most controversial moments.

This movie is a premiere example of the precocity of 1970's filmmaking.  It is long.  But it's long because it tells a complicated story.  Each scene really takes it's time.  But it uses this time to create, through fast realistic dialogue and overworked pauses, an amazing consternation. The acting was world class.  Hoffman and Redford really work off each other fantastically.  Their performance reminded me of Matthew McConaughey and Woody Harelson in the critically acclaimed 2014 TV series, True Detective.

Nowadays, with the flood of movies and media it's easy to overlook the classics but we need to remember the massive amount of work and care it once took to put together a film of this caliber.  That effort and care really translates when you watch it.  It's an experience that you just don't get in today's movies.  So make some popcorn, turn down the lights, and give this movie a watch.  You deserve it and you might learn some history in the process.

During the U.S. presidential campaign of 1972, Washington Post reporters Karl Bernstin and Bob Woodward investigated the break-in at the Democratic National Committee headquarters at the Watergate office complex in Washington, D.C.

An anonymous source from the FBI, nicknamed Deep Throat, began to leak information indicating there is something much more sinister hiding behind the scenes, but in the beginning journalists found it hard to belive and grasp the scale of it all. Through their investigation, the case of an ordinary burglary has grown into one of the biggest political scandals that have ever shook the U.S.

It turned out that the Committee to Re-elect the President (Richard Nixon) has engaged in serious political dirty tricks, harassment, espionage, etc. and that the Justice Department, the FBI and the CIA are involved in the cover-up. Scandal continued to unravel until it became clear that in the whole thing involved highest officials of the White House, including President Richard Nixon personally.

Movie All the President's Men was made in 1976, four years after the outbreak of the Watergate scandal and only two years after Richard Nixon was forced to resign because of this (and thus becoming the only U.S. president who resigned). The film received a great public attention, made a huge political influence in the United States, set new standards of journalism and became one of the most commercially successful political films in history.

In the scene when the two journalists are going towards the house of one of the key people in the scandal, one of them says: "All these neat, little houses and all these nice, little streets... It's hard to believe that something's wrong with some of those little houses." to which the other replies: "No, it isn't." This conversation sums up the disillusionment in the political system and the outrage of an entire generation. Based on actual events.
I'm biased due to the genre. An engaging watch from start to finish.

In the run-up to the 1972 elections, Washington Post reporter Bob Woodward covers what seems to be a minor break-in at the Democratic Party National headquarters. He is surprised to find top lawyers already on the defense case, and the discovery of names and addresses of Republican fund organizers on the accused further arouses his suspicions. The editor of the Post is prepared to run with the story and assigns Woodward and Carl Bernstein to it. They find the trail leading higher and higher in the Republican Party, and eventually into the White House itself.

Pakula follower the book and for the most part they did . This film captures the essence of a newspaper reporter and  journalism very well. A bonafide hit the political thriller "All The President's Men" garnered a total of Eight Oscar nominations including Best Picture and won Four including Best Supporting Actor, Best Adapted Screenplay, Best Sound and Art Direction.

 Dustin Hoffman as Carl Bernstein and Robert Redford as Bob Woodward ! Perfect.Jason Robards shines as their boss Ben Bradlee, and Hal Holbrook is quite great as Deep Throat- the key information provider to Woodward who managed to remain anonymous until 2005. 

All the President's Men is a quintessential American movie.

A suspenseful film take on Nixon's conspiracy for Watergate.

All the President's Men (1976) is director Alan J. Pakula's noir take on a political thriller centered around Watergate. The Nixon scandal changed American politics and how the public views The White House. The journalists Woodward and Bernstein are mostly responsible for enlightening and informing the American public about Nixon's criminal undertakings through their reporting at The Washington Post. All the President's Men chronicles the deep investigative reporting experience and the research that went into Woodward and Bernstein's work in uncovering the Watergate scandal. It's a riveting film from start to finish with moments that relate to modern day criminal proceedings in the Trump administration.

Pakula's direction is a gorgeous noir look with an espionage tale atmosphere akin to spy films instead of movies about journalists. All the President's Men has more in common with The Conversation, The French Connection, and Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy than it does with films like The Post or Spotlight funnily enough. Pakula's direction sees dark nights and long hours of conversing with witnesses, meeting with Deep Throat in dark smoky garages, and interviewing sources for investigative reporting. If the intrigue and scandal does not interest you, the fast paced footwork of these two reporters doing incredible and influential work certainly will. Pakula's direction is compelling as he pits journalists against their editor, readers, and their government. It's all interesting from any angle.

Robert Redford and Dustin Hoffman are phenomenal as Woodward and Bernstein, respectively. Redford captures Woodward's cool and thoughtful style of journalism with a kindly and clever reasoning process. Hoffman gives Bernstein a persistent and precocious attitude that is entertaining and insightful into the mind of a man that uncovered numerous Nixon accomplices. Redford and Hoffman both give engaging acting performances that are so realistic, you feel like you are just watching the events unfold on screen in front of you instead of watching a film. They captivate your attention with endless monologues of facts and lines of questioning. Redford and Hoffman's empathy is evident for Woodward and Bernstein's long hours of tireless and thankless work.

Overall, All the President's Men is worth watching just for the historical facts presented to you in an interesting way to give you everything you need to know about Watergate in the span of a film. All the President's Men just happens to entertain and engage you with creative noir filmmaking, stellar performances, and William Goldman's biting script.

I will say that you do takeaway from the film a bit more if you know your Watergate Scandal facts as well as having read the articles talked about in the film. That being said, I greatly enjoyed the film. To see the investigation from the point of view of Woodward and Bernstein is something that is rarely tackled in film. And when it does, the focus is mostly on the mystery of "Deep Throat" or the Nixon implications. This film does not do this and instead focuses on the intricacies of their investigation and everything they had to do to even get the first article out in the presses. My favorite aspect of the film would have to be the disuse of a traditional film score. This film relies on the diegetic sounds in order to not only build tension but also create a sense of realism. I would say that the only film to match this in recent memory to be David Fincher's The Social Network. Overall, I greatly enjoyed the film and want to say that Dustin Hoffman and Robert Redford did an amazing job playing some of the biggest whistleblowers in history.
A classic film about politics and journalism

Companion piece to The Post, but it blows The Post out of the water. Would never get green lighted these days. Two guys, no chemistry; reel off names for 2+ hours. It's gripping and brilliant.
This film was solid.

Pakula creates a remarkably absorbing drama that moves without hurry, following each step of a real-life journalistic investigation that should remind us of the absolute importance of a free press in democratic countries where powerful people still believe they can rise above the law.

Redford and Hoffman are excellent in this real life take on the watergate scandal which resulted in the axing of President Richard Nixon. Adapted from a book by the chief perpetrators that brought down the presidency, Journalists Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein, this film is so good you'd think it was a documentary. Stylishly shot by Alan J Pakula it has a documentarist vibe and feel (probably the filmstock) and the actors are all excellent- as they were back in the day. Robert Redford and Dustin Hoffman are really good as the two-investigative journalist's hell bent on finding the truth and everyone from Jason Robards and Hal Holbrook lend in finely tuned performances to give a lot of deft to the film. If you like political thrillers, then All the President's Men is a must watch.(One of the best political films ever made).

Such an important story to told, and it's fortunate that two major actors worked together to make it transcend generations.  Very interested to see the sequel - due out sometime during or after the 45th president's time in office.

This movie is about reporters doing their job, and really that's it.  It's incredibly well acted and directed, making it fun to watch if you like wonky history, or want to see how two hours of short conversations can be made actually fairly exciting.  But don't expect to learn much of anything about the men involved, personal struggles, or how they fit into larger issues in society.  To be sure, there are some subtle cues that are brilliant to watch, but the narrative sticks to its one track fairly obsessively.  The dialogue and acting are so good and so realistic that you feel like you are watching recordings of these conversations taking place.  Impressive, but the complete lack of exposition is actually a little painful to watch.  Finally, the ending was very disappointingly abrupt.  Did they just run out of steam, or what?
Very well done movie. Story flowed smoothly, movie seemed realistic, fine acting, and entertaining overall. Very interesting and thought provoking.
It's a 'life is stranger than fiction' story. So much intense stuff happens, if the film was fiction it would be condemned for being too fantastical. It's an intense, well acted mystery.

Alan J. Pakula made a very smart decision by not making this movie longer. Because I think Oliver Stone made a mistake by making the runtime of JFK three hours and nine minutes, and the director's cut even longer by 17 minutes! The result, in the case of JFK, was that the movie focused more than it should do on some subplots that really didn't add too much to the story. All the President's Men, instead, made a good use of every minute in it with its reasonable runtime. 

The Oscar-winner script, with all its cleverness, isn't the only powerful aspect about the movie. Alan J. Pakula directing is very entertaining. Besides building the tension, he shot many long scenes that really deserve to be of the most iconic scenes in film. 

The performances are all great; Redford has the most of the screen time, and I wouldn't have been surprised if he had an Oscar nod. He has a particular scene in which he changed his face expressions so gracefully. Hoffman is one of my favorite actors and he gave one of his best performances in this movie; his character is so energetic and impulsive and he just got it right. But the performance that really standout is Jason Robards' performance as Ben Bradlee, the executive editor of The Washington Post. Robards, without a doubt, deserved his Oscar for best supporting actor.

At the middle of its third act, I think the movie suffered a little bit moving between two sub-plots; it moved very fast between them and I think it should have made a small breather to keep me gripped, and to make me invested in the new sub-plot from its beginning.

There were many secondary characters in this movie and they were all great, except one character that I felt it should have given some more depth because it has an important role near the end, and a background could have filled some logical gaps. With that being said, this character is very interesting and you may be interested to search about it after watching the movie.

Overall, All the President's Men can be described as a "Hitchcockian" political thriller. Its tension and suspense are unprecedented in this sub-genre. And I loved it!

(8.5/10)

Seemed like an apt time to watch this one again...and it didn't disappoint.  Director Alan Pakula and famed screenwriter William Goldman manage to turn the gruelling legwork of the investigative journalist into a gripping thriller, despite it being all talk and no action (thanks also to the cinematography of Gordon Willis).  Of course, the focus of that investigation, as it uncovered more and more clues, was provocative and dangerous - as we know, reporters Bob Woodward (played by producer Robert Redford) and Carl Bernstein (played by Dustin Hoffman) effectively brought down Richard Nixon and his crooked administration.  Their source for "deep background" information (referred to as Deep Throat and played by Hal Holbrook) was a shadowy figure within the Executive Branch, not revealed in the movie nor by Woodward himself until 2005 when at age 91, former FBI Deputy Director Mark Felt outed himself.  Of course, all of the unattributed and off-the-record sources that they had to rely upon were immediately denounced and denied by the White House, but they were backed by gutsy Ben Bradlee (Jason Robards), editor of the Washington Post, their paper.  The filmmakers don't shy away from showing the grind of the investigation, the concern with journalistic ethics, the pressure from those trying to cover-up the links from the Watergate burglary at the Democratic National Committee headquarters to those higher up in Nixon's government - but it is never less than exciting as the pieces of the puzzle fall into place.  And rather than stretch out the story from its early beginnings (the break-in was 17 June 1972) all the way to Nixon's resignation (8 August 1974), the film ends with a series of teletypes showing the later dominoes falling.  Forty years later, the film itself has had an amazing cultural impact (perhaps beyond the book), giving us the phrase (and investigative plan) "follow the money" and influencing other scripts (notably The X-Files) and the training of journalists (apparently they watch the film).  So, the question arises - where are our Woodwards and Bernsteins today? We need them.

You may have heard of Watergate. This movie is based on the real-life experiences of Washington Post journalists Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein, who were the primary investigators of the scandal. I could tell you that this is the story of how they uncovered the truth of the Republican re-election committee's crimes in spying and sabotaging the efforts of the respective Democratic committee. However, that would not be entirely representative of what the story tells and how it is told. All the President's Men does not go into much detail about exactly how they cornered several committee members, including Nixon himself, to pleading guilty. See, this is not a feel-good movie. Instead, among their efforts to find on-record proof, we are treated to the details of their dead ends and shaky inferences. They barely have a clue as to what is truth and what is conspiracy; the closer they get to confirming the truth, the more fearful they are of the consequences of their actions. Director Alan Pakula crafts an atmosphere of paranoia through a figurative gas leak -- initially, an odd smell pervades the airs in attempts to interview witnesses, and overtime, Pakula seals the enclosure to test how much longer Woodward and Bernstein can breathe. And boy, do Rob Redford (Woodward) and Dustin Hoffman (Bernstein) choke. (Not as actors, to clarify.) The dark side of Washington DC shines best -- that is, the least -- in Woodward's visits to his government cohort Deep Throat (Hal Holbrook). These are the most hopeful times for Woodward to reach a revelation, but the revelations keep getting darker and darker, upon each visit. All the President's Men highlights how unglamorous the lifestyle of even the most heroic journalists is, as well as the sick, sinking feeling that comes with such investigation. The interpolations of real-life coverage on the government's responses to this investigation only further emphasize the horrors of their actions.

There's a scene in All the President's Men which lasts five minutes, contains four phone calls and is recorded in one take. It's a moment which speaks to what makes Alan J. Pakula's true to fact political thriller so affecting. It's a scene of piano string tension which refuses to blink, its drawn out take the visual equivalent of one holding their breath. It gives us no reprieve as the plucky journalist Bob Woodward pivots between callers, sensing he's on the cusp of a revelation as he surely begins to put one foot in front of the other. And when did that camera get in so tight to Bob's features? It slithered in, ever so gradually, from a medium shot to an extreme close up, just as we slowly lean forward in our chairs watching it. The fact that the camera is moving goes over our heads because it seems so natural, so befitting of the mounting excitement. 

It's this brand of theatrical flair which makes every minor moment of progress so dramatic in All the President's Men, where something as simple as ascertaining a name or receiving a nod of the head could set in motion a chain of events that has the weight to send America into disarray. It makes us covet every fact, it charges every second of the journalistic process with significance. The scene in question, as many scenes in the film do, risks being overwhelmed with information, it's confusing even for Bob who crosses the names of his callers, but it remains so completely thrilling because the film has installed in us an appreciation of our heroes and the fight required for even an inch of forward movement.

The action in the film amounts to little more than ink being scratched into paper and discussions of committee funds between reporters and government officials, but All the President's Men is never dry, never less than utterly absorbing. It's the story of two crusaders working for The Washington Post, a new comer Bob Woodward (Robert Redford), and a cutthroat veteran Carl Bernstein (Dustin Hoffman), who together dig into the Watergate break-ins and soon discover that whatever happened at the Democratic National Committee headquarters was far from a routine burglary. Of course the scandal was foul play from America's most important men, perhaps the pivotal moment in America's cancerous disillusionment which had become such a focal point for so many films in the preceding years. 

William Goldman's screenplay is one of extreme density, an endless spewing of names and locations and minute specifics, but it's dense to a fastidious end, not a tiring one. It's this amazing appreciation for detail that aligns us so tightly to our two investigators. We are with them for every forward step and backwards step, swimming in disparate information, begging for a rope as Woodstein (their adopted team name) themselves tread to keep the heads above water. We are so enveloped in their journey, so tremendously synchronised with them, that we almost forget where it is that the scandal, one of the most well known in history, is headed.

So much of the tension stems from the fact that Pakula and Goldman never do offer us a line. The film never leaves its circle of phone calls, note taking and interviews. We're never given a chance to see Woodward and Bernstein operate in their personal lives, their existence is instead constricted to the investigation. We only get to know them through subtle characterisations, like the chain smoking, coffee slurping Bernstein's hair which slowly grows out sideways as the case wears on; like Woodward's increasingly sloppy apartment which was a mess to begin with; through Woodward's relenting on interviewees while Bernstein wants to take no prisoners, as though to keep their morality in check as they stumble into increasingly immoral territory.
 
There's also a spookiness to the film, a spookiness at times painted with sub horror strokes that stray from realism. Woodstein are delving into an abyss, tackling a force which omnipotently presides over their every move like an Orwellian nightmare. The shadow enclosed Deep Throat (Hal Holbrook), the famed inside man who meets with Woodward in blackened car parks to nudge him in the right direction, registers like a Poe creation, a noir inflected ethereal presence who warns of danger and vanishes into darkness. Another element of what makes All the President's Men so thrilling is the fact that all men are the President's, a notion captured in Pakula's reoccurring pull back of his camera into a distant bird's eye view, reducing the journalists to specks in a Washington labyrinth that consumes them. They're waging a war against a dangerous, evil force which has them surrounded, a truly scary proposition.
 
It all makes us appreciate the tenacity of our battlers. In the end All the President's Men is most effective as a taut love letter to the tireless work of two men who never gave up on the truth. What Pakula and Goldman offer us are two working stiff heroes with an insatiable hunger, who like the filmmakers themselves, never underestimated the power of the smallest detail. It's a portrait which brings clarity to the near impossibility of dredging up morality in a changed America, and it brings clarity to the amazing bravery required for the task.

The third film in Alan Pakula's 'paranoia trilogy', this measured, naturalistic look at the breaking of Watergate might disappoint those looking for a more action-packed thriller. But it's a remarkable film and its unmannered style serves the subject matter well. Based on Woodward and Bernstein's own account, and released just two years after Richard Nixon's resignation, the film has become inextricably linked with Watergate itself. For many people, Redford and Hoffman ARE Woodward and Bernstein. Such is the power of  Hollywood to instantly mythologize the American past. William Goldman's taut screenplay deservedly won an Oscar and the acting and cinematography is excellent throughout. Like Oliver Stone's Nixon, which looks at Watergate from the other side, It can be hard to follow if you don't already know the basics of the scandal and the names of the various characters involved. Alternatively, you can forget about all that, and simply be borne along by the performances. It's a great film and the you can see its fingerprints all over later biopics, such as Spotlight from 2015.

Speaking to the infamous source "Deep Throat", Woodward has just about had it, along with colleague Carl Bernstein (Dustin Hoffman).  The two have been determined to uncover what we now know as the Watergate Scandal, and after a flurry of false leads, double-crosses, and vague communication, it's a story that could arrive with much gusto and alarm - it's a story that could propel them to journalism stardom in a flash and rip the dishonest Richard Nixon out of office.  They are frantic, and so are we.
	"All the President's Men" is now 38 years old, but it still holds the same power it did back in 1976.  When the facts came on display, it was a bold headline, jarring Americans everywhere.  Most of us don't realize exactly how long and how hard many journalists worked simply to tell the world that Richard Nixon is not a man you want in office - by the time the film is over, Woodward and Bernstein's triumphant findings are not only a landmark, but a showcasing of enduring patience that most would eventually give up over.
	Journalism today isn't the same as it was in the '70s, now that we can blog, use the assets of social media, and even more depressingly, glittery headlines with celebrities names stamped across them bring more attention than even the most important revelations about higher issues.  Woodward and Bernstein lived in a time where you had to find the phone numbers of leads, go to their houses to interview them, and jot down their quotes, while today we can simply email a person of interest in just a few minutes.  The pair of journalists have doors slammed in their faces, an uninterested public, and possible whistleblowers that would rather not talk to contend with.  
	The film is two-hours and 18 minutes, a reminder that "All the President's Men" isn't a regular political thriller, one that states the facts so fervently that we're constantly remember that this mystery took years to solve, not just a few days.  Pakula directs with patience that is covered in thickly spread tension - there are plenty of moments where we can feel the goodness of an aha moment that is felt by the reporters, with only seconds later finding that it's just another key to the puzzle and not a complete resolution.  The film is full of these disappointments, only reminding us that this isn't simply a product of Hollywood lure, but an absorbing piece of non-fiction.
	Robert Redford and Dustin Hoffman, two of film's biggest names, may be starring, but "All the President's Men" isn't merely a vehicle.  There are no love interests, no big-budgeted side steps; Redford and Hoffman transform from movie stars into average people on a mission in seconds.  Jane Alexander portrays a woman who has been silenced by her employers, fraught with guilt, showing us the side of the individuals who were told not to talk, frightened for their life if they do so.  Hashbrook's shadowed and enigmatic portrayal of "Deep Throat" gives the film the blackened, stone-cold question mark of a character that gives the mystery even more juice than it had before.
	It seems nearly impossible to write a review for "All the President's Men", because there are so few movies that move along and speak for themselves with such clarity and believability.  It's a gold mine of everything it takes to be a film for the ages, and to anyone who hasn't seen it, it's a must.

We have met the enemy, and they is more ours than we realized they was. Pakula's fact-based look at the way Woodward (Robert Redford) and Bernstein (Dustin Hoffman) uncovered the story behind the Watergate break-in is a classic piece of filmmaking that's influenced almost every, if not every, piece of film and television dealing with journalism that's come since in America. Most, thankfully, are a little more coherent than this, but the confusion factor doesn't make All the President's Men any less a film.

Much of what allows All the President's Men to straddle the line between confusing mush and classic
filmmaking is in that everpresent devil, the details. Want an example? The main theme of the film is that words are weapons; the unforgettable opening sequence, in which the typewriterkeys strike the paper with seemingly epic force, is the result of mixing whip and shotgun sounds with the actual sounds of typewriter keys. Now that's attention to detail, folks. As well, Pakula never allows the story to stray from the straight and narrow. Woodward and Bernstein remain the focus throughout, and while some minor characters get enough screen time to be memorable (Jason Robards' performance as Ben Bradlee garnered him a very well-deserved Best Supporting Actor oscar), we don't need to know who they all are; their function in the film is solely to either funnel information to, or keep information from getting to, Woodward and Bernstein. We don't need to know anything else about them. It adds a little kick to know trivial details, such as the guy playing Frank Wills (the security guard who discovers the break-in initially) actually was the late Frank Wills, but it's not necessary to comprehend the story of what started as a routine newspaper article about a hotel burglary and ended up being a series of articles that won the Pulitzer Prize, changed the face of political reporting in America, and incidentally saved Bob Woodward's job at the Washington Post. ***  1/2

   All The President's Men is a 1976 political thriller directed by Alan J. Pakula and written by William Goldman. IT stars Robert Redford, Dustin Hoffman, Hal Holbrook, Jack Warden, Jane Alexander, and Jason Robards. Redford and Hoffman play two investigative journalists working at The Washington Post. Redford plays Bob Woodward, a young, determined reporter with a passion for hard work and not giving up. He is thrown upon the job to investigate the Watergate Scandal with his co-worker, Carl Bernstein. Bernstein is played by Dustin Hoffman, whom at the time was well known for such films as The Graduate and Midnight Cowboy. Hoffman, who may quickly become one of my favorite actors, gives a great performance here. Redford and Hoffman's chemistry works well, and Redford gives a strong, determined performance as Woodward, and it shows no fault. Hoffman keeps up the "cool guy" feel throughout the film, and his hair adds much more to it. At first, the film felt like a Redford film, but not much. Slowly, though, it improved to become a side-by-side, duo partnership extravaganza, keeping a real partnership. At times, though, I felt a bit disconnected from the two and the two from each other. They worked together throughout the entire film and become strong partners, but it's hard to tell if they became "friends". They did, it's very well possible, and I can see it in the film, but the two discussed mostly only facts and opinions about the case, and not much about each other. The character development here was a draw back, for I did not learn much of either throughout the film, and while it kept the audience rooting, it couldn't keep me from caring much about these guys as personally as I would've. If not for their work to uncover Watergate and their familiar faces, I would not have cared much at all for either Bernstein or Woodward for I didn't anything about them personally and who they were outside of their work life. I'm not sure if this was from the acting, but Hoffman and Redford's chemistry both worked well, and I enjoyed them greatly. Jason Robards also starred in this film, and as I watched him in the movie, I thought to myself 'He could have been nominated for an Oscar." And sure enough, he had won the Best Supporting Actor Oscar. He absolutely deserved it as well, though, for his portrayal of a newspaper executive was the most hard and full performance in the film. All the other characters were pushed on by either mystery, need, desire, or progress, but Robards's character did not need these characteristics throughout the film to push him in the movie. Winning the Oscar the same year "Network" was released, Robards beat his way through tough competition and won the Oscar. I enjoyed him in his only other film I've seen him in, Once Upon a Time in the West, and seeing his change in character from that one to this was great and I enjoyed it. Robards to me brought a different character to the film that it needed, and he added life to it, not more investigation. The rest of the cast did well, such as Jane Alexander playing a startled and worried woman who has been thrown into the Watergate scandal. She was nominated for a Best Supporting Actress Oscar, and while I don't think it was to memorable to get the Oscar, it was a fine performance. Hal Halbrook and others play other mysterious characters, and a lot went into the casting of this film. And in total, the casting was actually made very well.

   Alan J. Pakula directed this film. And he directed other directors through this film, as well. One of the firs things I noticed about the direction of the film was how it must have greatly inspired one of my all time favorite directors David Fincher. The way the cameras moved through the journalist and writing tables was very much how it moved through films such as Zodiac and The Social Network. The direction truly was ahead of it's time, for if not for the seventies style of acting, I would've believed the film was made in the late eighties or nineties. Pakula uses not only excellent track shots through the journalists desks, but he also uses aerial shots, pans, excellent lighting to shroud actors, and much more. This film inspires many films today, for not only did the plot and acting change inspire many films, but the cinematography and the use of focus and zoom and many other cinematic tricks that films use today originated from this movie, and it shows all these achievements well. I had never heard of Pakula, though, before this film. Maybe his name sounded familiar, but I never heard of any great films from him, and whenever I heard of All The President's Men his name  never came up. It's a shame, for Pakula gave some fantastic direction in this film, and if not for the competition filled year of 1976, I'm sure Pakula would've won the Best Director Oscar. He  is very underrated and very under the radar, but if anything, he should be remembered for his work in this film. It is some work  that is hard to be rivaled.

   All The President's Men is adapted from a book of the same name, written by Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein. William Goldman took that book and wrote it the best he could to the film. I have never read the book, so I have no comment on the accuracy, but the writing in All The President's Men was real good, whether it was adapted well or not. The writing throws facts after facts after facts at you, which deterred from the character development, but it kept these facts coming at a steady pace. The memorable dialogue and quick-response dialogue show true through these characters, especially through Jason Robard's character. His lines are furious, hard, and well-written, and whatever he says on screen really mattered. To keep a plot like All The President's Men aligned, and to show everything that could've been shown about this long reaching scandal was difficult, and the viewer had to stay intact and listening to catch everything. The Watergate Scandal proves to be one of America's dark moments of the nineteenth century, and Goldman does a good job of keeping it in mystery throughout, slowly building it up to what the public fully realized in the seventies. One hardship of the writing, though, was the names and the confusion. At times, the film got a little to fast to keep up with, and many names and titles were thrown around. The audience could not keep up with all them, and although Goldman did good in rounding the plot up here and there through the movie, his screenplay was the weakest part of the film. Woodward and Bernstein went a little to fast themselves with the uncovering of the investigation, causing them to lose track and stumble here and there, therefor causing the viewers to lose track and stumble as well. It was something that could've been fixed if Goldman relaxed and let the audience watch and understand the film play out, instead of making them listen hard and struggle to keep up. Richard Nixon, though, resigned a mere two years prior to this films release, as well, so Goldman had a lot of work to do to uphold a film with a recent conflict such as Watergate. But Goldman, despite his pace and bulk in writing, took the recent events of Watergate, and made them timeless through his writing.

   All The President's Men came off to be a work of precision and good film. Redford and Hoffman worked together along with the rest of the cast to show the audience how journalists changed not only news, but the nation itself. The cast showed strong integrity and likeness throughout the film, despite lack of character development at times, and some of the cast also kept the film up and honest. Alan J. Pakula's direction should not go a missed, as it was strong and solid, only at times did it waver. His direction through the movie inspires many directors today, as he works with audience to keep them the way Woodward and Bernstein felt throughout the unfolding of the scandal. Woodstein would feel frustrated, and so would the audience. They'd feel relieved, and so would the audience. Pakula does this as well as paves the way for different directing work for many films to come, such as the use of aerial shots, focus, and much, much more. Alan J. Pakula directed ahead of his time, and at the same time bringing out a plot in a movie at it's time. Goldman writes well, only writing difficultly for the audience to keep up with at times, but his use of dialogue and facts in the movie keeps the film from going off track and keeping the film in focus of the bigger picture. Watergate was a long, hard difficult event to unfold, eventually resulting in one of America's largest embarrassments. From the break in to the hotel, to the resigning of Nixon, the audience sees how it all happens from the brilliant work of two investigative journalists. Pakula shows he can work a problem and mold it into a film so everyone can see how the problem truly came to light. And whether it be through film, through reporting, through word of mouth, or through public disapproval, it's hard to truly understand all of Watergate. But the people behind this film didn't find it to hard to still let the audience know that something like this did happen, and bring justice to the facts in which it was unraveled. It can almost make someone happy that it did happen. 8/10.

Set during the times of the Watergate scandal, All the President's Men (1976) follows the investigative reporting exploits of Washington Post journalists, Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein. Pakula who was known for his conspiracy films (The Parallax View, 1974) makes the film seem as real as possible.  The audience gets to see every single detail of the reporting process and this has the viewer really wanting both of these journalists to expose the corrupt government.  Beyond this is the significance of the film that has turned it into a classic.  It is the best portrayal of American journalism in American film.  There are other films that come to mind that represent the power of journalism (Mr. Smith Goes to Washington, 1939 and The Man who shot Liberty Valance, 1962, just to name a couple) but All the President's men looks in depth at what effort journalists need to exert when exercising this power.  The chemistry between Hoffman and Redford in the movie is perhaps its greatest strength and the scripts twists and turns help keep viewers on the edge of their seat the whole movie.  And while cinematography might not seem important in this movie, the camera work is great especially in scenes that involve Woodward talking to deep throat in the shadowy garage.  All the President's men is a intense, investigative thriller that not only entertains, but educates audiences on the importance and effect of the media in America.

All the President's Men is one of the most acclaimed films of its time for being a depiction of the lead up to the Watergate scandal at a time when people had been truly shocked by the ordeal. So for a person with a large curiosity towards Watergate which had not been answered by many other films such as Oliver Stone's Nixon which really should have considering that it was a Richard Nixon biopic, I had hopes to really learn a lot from All the President's Men. And with a cast containing both Dustin Hoffman and Robert Redford, it was simply a political thriller that I could not miss.

The issues that source from All the President's Men are the usual ones of a political thriller, being that the film maintains a slow pace over an extended period of time and is reliant more on talking that anything else to explain the story and the important meaning behind the effect it had on the world. So audiences who, like me, have not learned to adapt to the very theoretical nature of political thrillers may fail to find themselves immersed in the story of All the President's Men.
Also, the film suffers the same troubles that The Manchurian Candidate does today by being dated and featuring a story which would make a significantly stronger imact in its own time, or more appropriately in America where the story is more likely to be drilled into the brains of every High School Student for generations.
Also, All the President's Men can't decide whether it should be a film which maintains the large scale which reveals the impact of the Watergate scandal on the protagonists and the wider world or a character drama which reveals just the challenge it was for protagonists Carl Berlstein and Bob Woodward to bring forth a story that changed the world. It fails to truly find a balance and ends up dwindling between the two without settling on one or succeeding as both.  It's hard to connect to the film because the importance is more in the story than the characters, but it's also hard to feel the impact of the Watergate scandal since the emphasis is placed on the characters more than anything, so unfortunately I have to say that Alan J. Pakula's direction on All The President's Men is not some of his finest and fails to tie together enough of the story for it to truly seep into the minds of viewers.
Much like Robert Redford's 2007 political drama film Lions for Lambs, All the President's Men felt to me to be a rather distant film which felt like a series of lectures one after the other which never really reached the scale that it aimed for. Unfortunately though, All the President's Men deals with the truth in the story of Watergate escaping to the public from the people who know the truth, so the story is significantly more important. Yet still its scale feels all too small and it doesn't feel like there is ever energy in the development of the film. The atmosphere feels blank and lacking in the tension that should be there, and the only time I ever really felt something was when there was a musical score there to benefit the film. Unfortunately it barely ever makes an appearance when it could have made All the President's Men, and this is bad because it shows to make an impact when it is actually present.
While the story does succeed as a visual depiction of the events leading up to revealing the Watergate fiasco and the true story of Carl Berlstein and Bob Woodward as they changed the world, it doesn't really feel like it captures the essence of the impact they made it essentially reduces the story to the level of office politics. The scale of the film is too small for a historical event in which the scale and impact was so big, and so in my opinion All the President's Men was simply an overlong slow bore which I learned nothing from. Even though it was a well scripted one.
But I can say that I appreciated the acting in the film.
Robert Redford's lead performance is a powerful which is full of all the necessary tension in his facial gestures and line delivery, as well as a real tenacious look of promise to succeed in changing the world for the better. As Bob Woodward, Robert Redford embodies the role with a political passion and makes the film better. His ability to engage with the complex political universe and the people within it comes naturally to him, so his performance is a beneficial one for All the President's Men.
Dustin Hoffman is always going to be one of my all-time favourite actors, and while I didn't enjoy All the President's Men too much there is no denying the strength in his performance which makes him an amiable and friendly lead when he tackles the role of Carl Berlstein. I was a little disappointed that he didn't enter the film for a slightly long period of time, but he still did a good job.  His chemistry with Robert Redford is one of the key highlights of the film as they have a combination of determination and dedication put into both their roles make the film a more compelling effort in terms of its character drama, even though the film doesn't deliver as much as it should.
Hal Holbrook has to face a challenging role, simply because at the time the film was created the identity of "Deep Throats" had not been identified and so his account of the character is unidentified, but Hal Holbrook's successful characterisation of him has a certain grittiness andtense facial gestures reminiscent of Frank Sinatra in his prime. Hal Holbrook does a strongly effective job in the role.
And Jason Robards' natural talent as an actor is easy to see in All the President's Men because whilst his screen time is small, is confidence and talent is large and so he is definitely a memorable sight in the film.

So All the President's Men will find minimal trouble appealing to Watergate aficionados and fans of political thrillers, but as neither of those I honestly can begrudgingly say that I did not find All the President's Men as insightful, intelligent, educational or entertaining as I really hoped to.

Directed by Alan J. Pakula, this film formed the third part of an unofficial trilogy on paranoia that Pakula started with Klute (1971) and The Parallax View (1974). Based on the book by journalists Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein, adapted for film by William Goldman. It's a slow moving but well made and ultimately suspenseful film focusing on a few months which nearly compromised the American government. In June 1972, when five burglars are arrested for breaking into the Democratic National Committee headquarters at the Watergate Hotel in Washington. The Washington Post's editor Ben Bradlee (Jason Robards) assigns news reporter Bob Woodward (Robert Redford) to investigate why they did it, he learns that one of the arrested men James W. McCord, Jr. (Richard Herd) worked for the CIA, and that President Richard Nixon's Special Counsel Charles Colson, also has ties with the burglars. Bradlee assigns Carl Bernstein (Dustin Hoffman) to work with Woodward, and they work brilliantly together, but the complexity of the case makes it impossible to crack, but Woodward finds an anonymous source in "Deep Throat" (Hal Holbrook), who is able to help out. It's a good thriller, one where there's nary any action or murders, but it manages to be uncomfortable and intriguing. Hoffman and Redford play well off each other, and it captures the paranoid mood of America at the time. You can see where David Fincher got his inspiration for the look and feel of Zodiac (2007) from this.

The pre-eminent cultural document of one of modern America's most notorious political scandals, All the President's Men treats the Washington Post's gradually-accumulating Watergate investigation as the detective story it was. Visually arranged with clear-eyed economy by noted conspiracy-thriller director Alan J. Pakula from a script by William Goldman (writer of The Princess Bride and Butch Cassidy & The Sundance Kid), it proceeds with irresistible inertia and charm and not really a whole lot of simmering liberal outrage.

Indeed, considering the characterization of the Watergate investigation in general by movement conservatives as being driven by a liberal ideological vendetta against the reviled Richard Nixon, there's nary a hint of partisan affiliation at all in Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein's reporting efforts. Indeed, Robert Redford's Woodward even confesses to being a Republican to assuage such doubts raised by a potential source. Liberal Hollywood can be nothing if not careful when it comes to covering their collective political tracks in the effort to appeal to as wide an audience as possible, and this is evident here, despite the charged subject matter.

What the film does accomplish is the nearly-instant mythologizing of the reporting of "Woodstein" (a portmanteau for the two junior reporters amusingly coined by their irascible editor Ben Bradlee, a role which won Jason Robards a Best Supporting Actor Oscar). What ensues is a complex and intermittently tense narrative pitting plucky, smart good against smug, powerful, faceless evil, complete with plenty of earnest but reticent conservative functionaries agonizing over whether to reveal the extent of their own knowledge of official wrongdoing.

Its depiction of the moral agonies of the upper-middle-class aside, All the President's Men is iconic for more simple cinematic reasons. There's memorable visual touches, like the long crane shot pull-back of the reporters poring through documents in the Library of Congress, or Woodward's deeply atmospheric meetings with "Deep Throat" in a parking garage at night (both of which were parodied in a classic episode of The Simpsons). The dialogue is not as demonstrative in its cleverness as other Goldman scripts could be, but it skews towards sharp realism in its exchanges. So many of the key plot moments are marked by razor distinctions in language, and so much convoluted and clandestine detail from the book upon which it is based must be boiled down into more basic filmic terms, that Goldman's task was more to be precise and careful than to wheel free with unfettered wit.

We also have the stars, Redford as the presentable, stand-up Woodward and Dustin Hoffman as the hyperkinetic, suspicious Bernstein. Their portrayals have settled the respective public profiles of this most famous reporting team in American history for all time, although their subsequent career paths have helped that process. Woodward has become a venerable scion of Serious Journalism, regularly offering milquetoast conventional wisdom on current affairs talk shows and most recently penning sober stenographical non-exposés from inside of the Bush Administration, whose wasteful pre-emptive wars based on false premises and illegal detention and torture regime puts that infamous "second-rate burglary" in perspective a bit. Bernstein is not exactly a non-establishment figure, but has shown a more consistent distrust of institutions than Woodward has since Watergate, at least. One can mostly extrapolate their professional trajectories from the way the actors have approached them as characters.

If the film has a particular problem, it's with how it ends, with the clacking teletype exposition of the eventual unraveling of the Watergate cover-up that led to Nixon's historic resignation as President. The more specific focus that Goldman and Pakula have chosen makes for the tighter film, but also prefigures a story larger and more unwieldy than film narrative can quite accommodate (some of the more bizarre details of the larger story can only be hinted at; Kenneth Dahlberg's apparent evasive tactic of claiming to be traumatized by his neighbour's kidnapping drops like a joke, but he wasn't kidding, she really was kidnapped for a ransom). As with much of the political world, the truth is not only stranger than fiction but more labyrinthine and multifarious as well. Even as All the President's Men displays an understanding of this, the film pushes for simplification whenever it can. As such, strong as it is, it's more of an engaging synopsis of Watergate than a comprehensive document of it. Could a movie be anything more, or anything less?

All the President's Men begins with the break in of the Democratic Part Headquarters at Watergate, and then goes on to two unlikely journalists covering the event - Dustin Hoffman's Carl Bernstein and Robert Redford's Bob Woodward. The two, especially Hoffman, may appear naive and inexperienced, but as the plot went on, I could at once see what a gross underestimation that was. From beginning to end, these two personify and symbolize the champions of a free press. And here's the icing on the cake - Woodward was a real-life Republican even then: but that never stopped him and Bernstein to courageously track down and encumber the hidden corruption in the Nixon Administration. That should serve as a lesson to all those politically affianced journalists of today, to whom objectivity is but a mere thing of the air. Hoffman and Redford act together with such clarity, that in the end, I felt All the President's Men to be one very definitive based-on-real-life-events film. The ending was superbly done - a montage of typewritten newspaper headlines culminating in Nixon's impeachment. This is one very good journalism-oriented film, and with some elements of life-and-death thrills, plus some very suspenseful and nail-biting speculations (especially with Hal Halbrooks' Deep Throat hanging around with Woodward), I highly recommend this.

A brilliant film. A gem of a political thriller. You have to be a good writer to make present investigative journalism in such a compelling way. And you have be a great writer to present the worst scandal in American history in such a delicate and eye-opening way. For those watching in 2011, to watch All the President's Men is to know the horror and disappointment Americans felt in the early 1970s. It's to see how shocked and betrayed America felt like in the eyes of journalist Bob Woodward (Robert Redford) as Deep Throat (Hal Holbrook) told him in that dark parking garage that the corruption went all the way to the top, forever shaking people's faith in the White House. The acting was superb. Holbrook, even with his face in shadow captured the menacing words and feel of Deep Throat perfectly. Jason Robards played the senior editor of The Washington Post well and there was also Dustin Hoffman (Midnight Cowboy, The Graduate). This film bookended by historic video reels of President Nixon and damning newspaper headlines captures the irony of Nixon's re-election in the face of his sins. Viewers will feel the weight of his hubris in blatantly deceiving the American people and thinking he could get away with it, despite Nixon never appearing in the film. All the President's Men will continue to astound for decades more to come; no other film since has ever been able to tell this painful chapter in American history quite as well.
